Refactoring. Switch from a boolean to an Enum for error state so we can differentiate between an error that requires the connection is closed after the current response is completed and an error that requires that the connection is closed immediately. This commit should be a NO-OP. While the different error states are set, the only the presence of an error (or not) is tested - i.e. no change from the implementation prior to this commit. Try to be consistent when an error occurs. Set the status code first (if required), then set the error state and finally log (if required).git-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@1600109 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Move conversion to SubmitRecords into SubmitRuleEvaluatorMuch of this logic is shared between TestSubmitRule andnChangeControl.canSubmit(), which both depend on this output format.nMove the logic into SubmitRuleEvaluator to lessen the leakage of Termnobjects.nnThe main difference in behavior between these two classes is hownerrors are treated. canSubmit() is called by non-admin end users whonget bland error messages telling them to check the server logs;nTestSubmitRule is for admins who need to debug submit rules, andnerrors are expected to happen. So we need to distinguish the case whenndetailed error messages should go to the user vs. in the logs. Do thisnexplicitly with a setLogErrors() method on SubmitRuleEvaluator.nnChange-Id: Ia61310e4fb6dea255ab721893eea070ca95d216cn

Checking in the modified ( and new ) files.Most of the functionality in Main is moved into AntBean ( all public/protectednmethods are now wrappers around AntBeans functionality, for backward compat).nnSame in ProjectHelper - again, for backward compat the public/protected functionsnare unchanged, old code can still call the old methods and get similar behavior.nnnIn TaskAdapter - few improvements ( still more to go ) to allow a programnto control tasks that are in a child loader. Thats extremely important tonget ant embeded and controlled in a programatic way ( Project may createntasks in a child class loader, so casting will fail - the only waynto use them is by using introspection ). Ive also added the abilitynto adapt beans that have multiple methods, not only execute()nnPlease review, try, let me know when I can commit it.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@271514 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Refactor to improve readability of comparisons

This is a major change. :-)It introduces the concept of a TaskContainer to allow a task to containnother tasks. This allows Task compositionnIt introduces a <parallel> task for multithreading support. There isnalso a <sequential> task.nIt reworks System.out management to handle all task generated outputnand route it through the Ant event system. This handles multithreadednoutput.nnThis is a major rework to the patch originally submitted by Thomas. Inhave taken a different route for the output management, in particular.nnBased on patch by Thomas Christen <chr@active.ch>nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@269371 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Remove gwtjsonrpc types from new REST APIOnly rely on native GWT supplied interfaces like the GWT version ofnAsyncCallback and StatusCodeException. Redesign change screen on new REST APIThe new screen exists at #/c2/<id> as it is missing a large number ofnfeatures.  The proposal is to include the screen as-is and iterate inntree, similar to the CodeMirror work.  This allows power users tonstart trying the screen out by editing the URL.nnMissing features:n- Add reviewer(s)n- Remove reviewer(s)n- Edit commit messagen- Diff files in two patch setsn- Dependencies and dependentsn- Download links by URL and action (cherry-pick, checkout, etc.)nnChange-Id: Ie957fb85c873d044c947000f0f0207a66f87c784n

Add real side-by-side compare for 2-way diffsThe HTML for the table is built up in a string builder thennshoved in as the innerHTML property of the <tbody>. This isnsignificantly faster than creating DOM nodes from code.  Bynthis approach the rendering is almost instant; creating DOMnnodes takes over 3 seconds for some simple files.nnIn theory N-way diffs can also be drawn on the client side,nbut the backend for the detail RPC call doesnt create thencontent correctly, and hyperlinks dont exist to get intonthe sidebyside mode for an N-way diff.  We may add supportnfor it in the future.nnSections which are ellided out by the patch (because theynare common) dont render, and theres no way to increasenthe context.  We also dont honor any sort of user contextnpreference yet, rendering only the context that the patchnitself came out of the database with.  By default this isn5 lines.nnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Cleanup c3p0 connection pools if usedJetty and c3p0 leak all of the connections unless our own applicationntells c3p0 to cleanup while Jetty is winding down the context in ordernto load it again.  Theres some sort of disconnect in the standards,nor in the Jetty code, where the c3p0 DataSource pool doesnt get GCdnautomatically.  In order to close the connections down we need to dona destroy on the pool ourselves.nnSince we dont want to make c3p0 a hard dependency we invoke destroynvia reflection.nnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Non blocking polling information. This implementation in pure Java NIO is almost a mimic of the APR implementation. It blocks on read and write, but has non blocking polling capabilities. Currently the read/write blocking is busy blocking, but I will see if I can simply configure blocking for the socket and if that would still allow the poller to work as expected. This makes it a suitable connector for comet style protocols and where APR is not desired or available.git-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/tc6.0.x/trunk@416187 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Test conversion of corrupt changes with GERRIT_CHECK_NOTEDBConsistencyCheckerIT creates various kinds of corrupt changes that wenthink might exist in the wild. In most cases, the right thing to donwhen converting these changes is to do our best and store *something*nin NoteDb, even if it cant be successfully read back. At the verynleast this allows admins to go in and manually edit the change, usingninteractive rebase in the same way they might poke the SQL databasentoday. This is preferable to throwing the data away during conversion.nnThe one time we cant do this is when the change belongs to a deletednproject. For now, we actually just discard these changes.nnRework the NoteDbChecker loops so that we attempt to convert allnchanges before checking any. This doesnt make ConsistencyCheckerITnpass, but it does let us verify from the stack trace that allnconversions were successful, even though changes couldnt be readnback.nnChange-Id: I87caa451db4e049fa3fc494b79c6c036fba36b1an
Add messages to the change detail screenThe message content is an overall remark about the change.nnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Workaround Guice bug getPathInfo not decodedDue to the Guice issue [1] cloning of a repository with a space in itsnname was impossible. If the space wasnt encoded:nn  $ git clone http://gerrit/My Projectnnthen such a request failed already in Jetty code.nIf the space was encoded:nn  $ git clone http://gerrit/My+Projectnnor:nn  $ git clone http://gerrit/My%20Projectnnthen the HttpServletRequest.getPathInfo in the GitOverHttpServlet wouldnreturn a non-decoded string i.e. My%20Project and the project wouldntnbe found. The HttpServletRequest.getPathInfo is expected to return andecoded string [2].nnUnfortunately, there is no Guice release which contains the bugfix fornthe issue [1].nnWorkaround: decode the projectName in the GitOverHttpServlet.Resolvernexplicitly.nn[1] https://github.com/google/guice/issues/745n[2] http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/7/api/javax/servlet/http/HttpServletRequest.html#getPathInfo()nnChange-Id: I8872cd2d1bab3f8e454d0d7399b35eb850068042n

Add a groups field to PatchSetThis field is intended to be used as an explicit replacement for thencurrent Related Changes heuristic, which may involve walkingnarbitrary amounts of history and making lots of database lookups innthe case of some merge topologies. With this field in the index, wencan implement GetRelated using a single secondary index lookup once wenknow the patch sets group identifiers. Combined with the storednPatchSet field, this gives us the entire set of commits that need tonbe considered for rendering the Related Changes tab, and the onlynremaining work is to do a simple walk to determine the relative toponordering.nnAny idea of automatically grouping changes together requires somenamount of heuristics, so we use opaque string values in this field inncase we decide to change heuristics later. If we change heuristics,nold groups will still be valid as long as the relevant changes staynthe same. (We might also decide to add a way to manually group changesntogether; today, this use case is largely handled by other featuresnsuch as topics, but this implementation does not rule that out.)nnThe field is actually multi-valued, as the heuristics we implementednin GroupCollector multiple groups if it is the merge commit of twondistinct branches of open changes. However, since we dont need tonlook up changes in the database by group, its not worth the effortnof an extra SQL table, so we just concatenate groups together.nnAnother useful feature of this implementation is that groupninformation is preserved when changes are closed, so submitting anchange will no longer immediately cause the Related Changes tab tondisappear.nnUse GroupCollector to assign groups in both the main ReceiveCommitsncase and the schema upgrade (for all open changes). See thendocumentation of GroupCollector for how this is intended to work.nnFor code paths other than ReceiveCommits, the rules are much simpler,nbecause there is only one change involved in the operation. Dependingnon the context, we simply either copy the existing group of the latestnpatch set, or we create a new group.nnChange-Id: I7cef275772882b045be14fd9bbbe7c52c73da2a8n

Pass project to ChangeData so that it can load the change from notesChangeData currently loads the change directly from the database, butnnow when we support notedb it should load the change via the changennotes factory. Loading the change via the change notes factorynrequires the project name in addition to the change ID, hencenChangeData must know it.nnThe only caller of ChangeData that cannot provide the project name isnHasDraftByLegacyPredicate. Due to this HasDraftByLegacyPredicatenloads the changes on its own from the database for now. We may removenthis deprecated predicate before migrating to notedb or find anothernsolution later.nnWhen the change is now loaded from notedb its last modified timestampnis only precise to seconds, while when its loaded from the database itnis precise to milliseconds. Due to this different changes got the samenlast modified timestamp when notedb was enabled and as result thenGetRelatedIT#getRelatedReworkThenExtendInTheMiddleOfSeries testnstarted to fail. Defining a 1s time clock step for this test fixesnthis issue.nnChange-Id: Iee0dce795766f543c996d75fde4067cb23a357ddnSigned-off-by: Edwin Kempin <ekempin@google.com>n

More plumbing for write. Generally:  - uses a state machine to co-orindate writes across multiple threads  - all writes are done on the main Connection thread, not on the Stream threads  - if there is a read thread, see if we need to (and can) write when it finishes  - written with an eye on non-blocking IO but that side of things isnt fully thought throughAlso some improvements to debug logging. Added a connection ID and made logs slightly less verbose.nngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@1680661 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

This is pretty muchn  just a placeholder until the new filter streams are ported across from ant 1.nn* Renamed Filter -> SingletonTokenSet.  This is a TokenSet that contains an  single mapping.  Moved to antlib.core.nn* Added PropertyTokenSet, a TokenSet that uses the project properties asn  its mappings.  Added to antlib.core.nn* Split FilterSet into TokenLineFilter, which is a LineFilter that replacesn  tokens with their value, and FileTokenSet, which is a TokenSet loaded fromn  a properties file.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@271869 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

The format of the note is like:nnChange-Id: I1745af1cb850829d9d3076cf41fba7845cdc0a63nCode-Review+2: John Doe <john.doe@example.com>nVerified+1: John Doe <john.doe@example.com>nSubmitted-by: John Doe <john.doe@example.com>nSubmitted-at: Mon, 27 Dec 2010 14:44:17 +0000nReviewed-on: https://review.example.com/123457nProject: projectNamenBranch: refs/heads/masternnTo view such notes locally one has to make sure that the refs/notes/reviewnbranch is fetched and use the --show-notes=review option of the git logncommand.nnCurrently, a note is not created for merge commits created by gerrit.nnThe changes done on the refs/notes/review branch are also scheduled fornreplication.nnThe NoteMapMerger from JGit is now used to merge conclicting note changes.nnChange-Id: I1745af1cb850829d9d3076cf41fba7845cdc0a63nSigned-off-by: Sasa Zivkov <sasa.zivkov@sap.com>nBug: issue 64n

Rewrite UI plugin action description APIUsing methods on an interface that plugins/extensions implementnmakes for a very brittle API. We cannot safely add a new methodnwithout breaking all existing code or introducing another interfacenfor plugins to implement.nnChange the UI action description to be a single method interfacenthat returns an instance of a concrete description object. Pluginsncan populate the fields they know about and need for their use case,nand the server will do its best to honor what the plugin has given.nNew methods can be added to the description without affecting thenAPI versioning, enabling Gerrit to add more features in the future.nnThe confirmation message feature has been removed. In the nearnfuture plugins will have the ability to register JavaScript codento be executed client-side when the button is activated and beforenthe RPC is started. This will allow plugins to perform more customnlogic, such as obtaining additional input.nnLooking even further ahead plugins may register their own JS handlernto render a button, allowing the plugin to use a more complex widget.nThe UiAction.Description type may need to be extended to allownserver side view code to pass custom data to the UI rendering logic.nnChange-Id: If5e0e6b42d6d1e8a111a2d304ce54b9d8834688an

Re-work EL attribute parsing. The underlying issue was complete independence of attribute and EL parsing. The attribute parser would generate the same result - ${1+1} - after parsing ${1+1} and ${+1} and the EL had no way to differentiate between the first (that should be treated as an expression) and the second (that should be treated as a literal). The attribute parser has been modified to output any literals that would be mi-interpreted by the EL parser as EL literals. ie  is output as ${} or #{}, $ as ${$} or #{$} and # as ${#} or #{#}.git-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@897614 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Init plugins AllRequestFilters, even if they are loaded after startupWhen installing a plugin with AllRequestFilters after Gerrit has beennstarted up, the filters doFilter is called as expected. But thenfilters init method is never called, as FilterProxy did not keepntrack of which filters have been around when its own init got called.nnThis lack of calling init, breaks the Filter contract, and makes thenjavamelody plugin throw NPEs [1] for each request when installing itnin a running Gerrit. While restarting Gerrit renders the javamelodynplugin working, the root problem is the missing call to thenfilters init.nnHence, we make FilterProxy call init for plugins that did not getninitialized when FilterProxy itself got initialized. Thereby, thenjavamelody plugin can be loaded directly into a running Gerrit again.nn[1]n  [2015-08-03 23:20:01,379] WARN  org.eclipse.jetty.servlet.ServletHandler : /n  java.lang.NullPointerExceptionn  at net.bull.javamelody.MonitoringFilter.doFilter(MonitoringFilter.java:170)n  at com.googlesource.gerrit.plugins.javamelody.GerritMonitoringFilter.doFilter(GerritMonitoringFilter.java:73)n  [...]nnChange-Id: I095ef517210911c982438d8ce3a7740d05c27eeen

Migrate ApprovalTypes away from ApprovalCategory(Value)Many callers of ApprovalTypes depend directly on ApprovalCategory andnApprovalCategoryValue, which are the types stored in the database. Wenwant to move away from storing approval categories in the database innfavor of arbitrary labels that can be defined on a per-project level,nincluding implicitly in submit rules. Leaking the database typesnaround the code makes this harder.nnReplace ApprovalCategoryValue everywhere except the database code withna similar and more concise LabelValue type. Use Strings instead of thendatabase Id types when referring to labels in general. In the shortnterm this may create some confusion in the code (alleviated,nhopefully, by documentation and variable names), since some places usenlegacy category IDs as unique keys and others use new style labelnnames as unique keys. In the long term we will stop using category IDsnexcept to map them to unique label names.nnUnlike ApprovalCategory, the new and improved ApprovalType does notndistinguish between the label name and the human-readable name.nGenerally these do not vary significantly other than the label namenhaving dashes instead of spaces, which is minor enough in the UI. Thenother affected functionality here is searching by label; since labelnnames can no longer contain spaces label:CodeReview no longer works,nonly label:Code-Review.nnChange-Id: I6854259d60af88b6d9df8d7553120a9af64c74adn

Add POST /changes/{id}/revisions/{sha1}/reviewClients can post a code review scoring and comments using a JSONnREST-style API. The API accepts change specifications using either thentriplet project~branch~change_id or the legacy _number format, andnalso accepts commit SHA-1 or legacy patch set id to identify whichnpatch set the comments apply too. Clients should prefer to use commitnSHA-1 to write comments, especially from automated builders where thencommit was just checked out.nnComments may include a top level cover message, updated scores fornlabels (previously approval categories), and inline file comments:nn  POST /changes/gerrit~master~I9589cc46b.../revisions/fe7ffc.../reviewn  Content-Type: application/json;charset=utf-8nn  {nmessage: Thank you for starting this project, it is useful.,nnlabels: {n  Verified: 1,n  Code-Review: -1n},nncomments: {n  gerrit-gwtui/src/main/java/com/google/gerrit/client/rpc/RestApi.java: [n{ line: 1, message: Is the copyright notice date correct? },n{ line: 32, message: Great idea, but try ...}n  ]n}n  }nnLabels are merged with the already existing labels for the callingnuser. This allows updating independent categories from unrelatednprocesses, such as two different build systems testing on Linux andnMac OS X. Callers can erase a label by setting it to 0.nnLabel names are free-form in the JSON map, but the server still needsnto restrict labels to those declared in the approval_categories tablenas it needs a category_id value to link the score to the patch set innthe database. This will change in the future as we fix more of the UInand server code to not have this requirement.nnBy default the POST is rejected with a 403 Forbidden error if a labelnis used in a way that is not permitted by the caller, e.g. trying tonassign Code-Review+2 will fail unless the caller has that permission.nClients can request these permission errors to be ignored by settingnthe top level property strict_labels: false in the request:nnstrict_labels: false,ntlabels: { Code-Review: 2 },nnIf a label is used without permission the value will be squashed tonthe highest (or lowest) value permitted to be used by the caller. Ifnthis value is 0, the label wont be set.nnInline file comments can also be supplied using the comments map. Keysnare file names, with lists of comment objects holding line number andnmessage text. All comments must be supplied during the POST. If thenuser has any drafts these will be erased when the comments are storednand published. In a future commit the web UI will be rewritten to usenthis RPC and will include all draft comments anytime it publishes.nThis will simplify last-minute edits of inline comments, as they cannbe updated without needing to wait for drafts to save.nnDrafts may optionally be published or left in draft status by settingnthe drafts field to another value:nn  drafts: DELETE,   // Delete non-updated drafts (default behavior).n  drafts: PUBLISH,  // Publish non-updated drafts now.n  drafts: KEEP, // Leave non-updated draft in draft status.nnThis commit copies a lot of code from PublishComments and refactors itnto a cleaner implementation. As soon as the web UI switches to the newn/review REST API call, PublishComments will be deleted, so no attemptnis made at sharing a common implementation.nnChange-Id: Iee7b4dcaa28cfc83f585ff99e3ed705973a2788dn

Implement OpenID based single-sign-on for Google AccountsThis is the early part of our OpenID based SSO implementation.nWe now support authentication through the Google Accounts OpenIDnprovider, allowing users to sign in and sign out of thenapplication through the external provider.nnPresently the login servlet is hard-coded to only use Google Accountsnas an OpenID provider.  We should support other providers by settingnup the standard OpenID entry box as the initial content returnednfrom our login dialog.nnThe login servlet randomly generates its coookie encryption keynduring startup.  This causes any existing user cookies to becomeninvalid, requiring the user to authenticate again.  At some pointnthis needs to change to obtain the encryption key from a localnstore, where it isnt part of the code base but is preserved acrossnapplication server restarts.nnIn the future we should also support other web based login systems,nsuch as any in-house web application (such as those used by manynlarge companies) or just plug in a basic LDAP or database based webninterface, without requiring the complexity of an OpenID provider.nnThe left and top menu now updates to reflect the current status ofnthe user.  If the user signed in we show the mine links and wenoffer the admin menu and a link to the users account settings.nnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Add a /changes option to include detailed label infoThe intent of this option is to be able to render the ApprovalTablenusing the new REST API. As such, we need to display detailed approvalninfo for all relevant accounts, not just the output of the submit rulenevaluator. The submit rule evaluator only outputs at most one accountnfor approved/recommended/disliked/rejected, and omits the numericnvalue.nnDetailed label information is included in the labels field, which isnall per-change information. The permitted ranges for the current user,nwhich is of course per-user, is included in the top-levelnpermitted_labels field.nnExample JSON output for a change:nn  {nkind: gerritcodereview#change,nid: repo1~master~I190d6f46480fbc160561bea7e46d1c0905d75a80,nproject: repo1,nbranch: master,nchange_id: I190d6f46480fbc160561bea7e46d1c0905d75a80,nsubject: Add bar/baz,nstatus: NEW,ncreated: 2013-01-29 21:37:03.870000000,nupdated: 2013-02-06 00:17:26.751000000,nreviewed: true,n_sortkey: 0022ea3100000002,n_number: 2,nowner: {n  _account_id: 1000000,n  name: Dave Borowitz,n  email: dborowitz@google.comn},nlabels: {n  Verified: {nall: [n  {nvalue: 1,n_account_id: 1000000,nname: Dave Borowitz,nemail: dborowitz@google.comn  }n],nvalues: {n  -1: Fails,n   0: No score,n  +1: Verifiedn}n  },n  Code-Review: {nall: [n  {nvalue: 1,n_account_id: 1000000,nname: Dave Borowitz,nemail: dborowitz@google.comn  },n  {nvalue: -1,n_account_id: 1000001,nname: David Borowitz,nemail: ddborowitz@gmail.comn  }n],nvalues: {n  -2: Do not submit,n  -1: I would prefer that you didnu0027t submit this,n   0: No score,n  +1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve,n  +2: Looks good to me, approvedn}n  }n},npermitted_labels: {n  Code-Review: [n-1,n 0,n+1n  ]n}n  }nnChange-Id: I97e97fa0cb27cc3dbdc8496d5115dc353dafc9aen

Implement full query operatorsAll of the change list pages have been rewritten in terms of thennew query operator implementation.  If the query exactly matchesna particular navigation call, we use the same underlying functionnto scan the database, which gives us about the same performance.nnRather than showing custom page titles, all of the change list pagesnupdate the search bar and show the underlying query.  This helpsnusers to learn what search operators Gerrit supports internally.nnIf the query has additional filter restrictions, we try to pick anreasonable scan function to read from the database, but then usenfilters inside of the JVM to whack out rows that do not match.nThe scan function selection is based on a hand-coded cost basednquery rewriter, which is really more of a rule based optimizer thannit is a cost based optimizer.  Its rather horrible at picking a goodnquery plan, but its good enough given the limitations of the gwtormnaccess API that we can still do something reasonable for the user.nnBecause the query graph is stored in memory as a proper graph,nwe may be able to later perform some optimization work where wentransform the graph into a proper SQL SELECT statement and handnit off to the database server for execution.  For most SQL systemsnthis would outperform what we do now.nnBecause the query rewriter edits the query, it may produce an invalidnresult sometimes.  Any old hand-coded search is correct, because thenrewriter just transforms to the same underlying function that we usednto have.  More complex filters may still uncover bugs in the rewiter.nnSome queries are simply not executable.  For example, is:reviewednwont execute, because we dont have a way to scan the databasenalong that dimension.  The access method doesnt exist simplynbecause the result set would be too large to reasonably process.nnThe set of operators is still not complete.  We should supportnthings like age:3d to mean changes that were last modified morenthan 3 days ago, but we dont yet.  Doing so efficiently probablynrequires converting the age specification into a sortKey and usingnan existing scan operation along that column.nnQueries once parsed into a predicate tree can be tested against ansingle ChangeData object, to consider just that one change.  Thisnwill later be useful for more powerful project watch specifications,nor access control rules.nnBug: issue 259nBug: issue 287nBug: issue 239nBug: issue 504nChange-Id: Ifdf7306bb362484c58df5785054fd9e43363aaa9nSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Fix https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=49884This required a major re-factoring of the async implementation. In summary:n- Moved state management to the Coyote Processorn- Added a SocketWrapper to the APR socketn- Added syncs to ensure only one async state change at a timen- Added syncs to ensure only one thread changing a sockets state at a timennA number of new bugs were also uncovered and fixed by this re-factoring:n- delay processing complete() and dispatch() until request where startAsync() is called finished processingn- onAsyncStart listener eventnnCurrently the test case for bug 49884 passes with the security manager enabled using ab -n 5000 -c 150 -k ... (it broke with ab -n 50 -c 10 ... previously) nnThe unit tests pass for all three HTTP connectors.nnThe AJP connectors have only been modified to ensure the code compiles.nnThe following work remains:n- Testing all connectors (HTTP and AJP) with TCK + security manager and fixing whatever is brokenn- Further clean-upn- There is further scope for reducing code duplication between the connectors / aligning the code so it is easier to maintain.nngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@1001698 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Prevent test.git.git turning into test.git in the Changes table.Prevent test.git.git turning into test.git in thenChanges table even though the project name is really test.nnGerrit drops the project names trailing .git suffix like:nn p  -> pn p.git  -> pn p/.git -> p.nnthen Gerrit try to search p in cache, if Gerrit cannot find p inncache, Gerrit will check disk repositories with name p, p/.git andnp.git in order.nnSo once users provide test.git.git, Gerrit firstly convert it intontest.git, then search test.git in cache, then search test.git,ntest.git/.git, test.git.git in order in the disk repositories.nSo if test.git exists on disk, Gerrit will return it back and stopnsearching test.git/.git or test.git.git.nnBut in fact Gerrit should search test.git/.git or test.git.git onnthe disk repositories, the logic is:nn ---------------------------------------------------------------n  users provide  | search in cache|  search in disk repositoriesn ----------------+----------------+-----------------------------n p |   p  |  p or  p/.git or p.gitn p/.git|   p  |  p or  p/.git or p.gitn p.git |   p  |  p or  p/.git or p.gitn ----------------+----------------+-----------------------------n  p.git/.git | p.git|  p.git/.git or p.git.gitn  p.git.git  | p.git|  p.git/.git or p.git.gitn ----------------+----------------+-----------------------------nnThis patch fix this bug based on this logic, thus in the case ofnissue 1699 Gerrit will not think of test.git on disk as the providedntest.git.git, so reject the push command and will not create dirtyndata any more.nnBug: issue 1699nChange-Id: I1a884b1e9c95fb940af5d9e8d3d5a074e6388da5

Let login fail if user name cannot be setWhen a user logs in for the first time in Gerrit annew account is created for this user. Depending onnthe authentication type a user name might benincluded in the authentication request. This usernname is then set for the newly created account.nIf setting this user name fails (e.g. because itnis already taken) the login still succeeded and thenerror was just logged. This makes sense if the usernis allowed to manually set a unique user namenlater. However in case the realm does not allownthe user to set a user name it results in annaccount for which no user name is set and fornwhich also no user name can be set. Such annaccount is not fully functional. This is why innthis case it is better to let the login fail andnprevent the creation of such an account.nnThis fix is especially important if e.g. LDAP isnused for authentication and the user verificationnin the LDAP system is case insensitive. E.g. itncould be that a user Guest exists in the LDAPnsystem and the user logs in with Guest intonGerrit which will create a new account in Gerritnwith Guest as Gerrit ID and Guest as externalnuser name. If now the user logs in into Gerritnwith guest Gerrit was creating a new accountnwith guest as Gerrit ID but the setting ofnGuest as external user name for this accountnfailed because it was already used for the accountnwith the Gerrit ID Guest. So the user ended upnwith two accounts in Gerrit from which one wasnnot usable due to the missing user name. Obviouslynthis can cause quite some confusion (e.g.nprivileges are assigned to one account, user logsnin with the other account and wonders why hisnprivileges are lost).nnSigned-off-by: Edwin Kempin <edwin.kempin@gmail.com>nChange-Id: Id03036119c7f9a24b50addfe410018a45762e1c3n

Add diff preferences panel to SideBySide2The diff settings are accessible by the , key. They are shownnon a PopupPanel that is similar to KeyHelpPopup and is placednon top of the CodeMirror on the left.nnAlmost all settings are applied immediately after the control widgetnhas been updated with its new value.  Because CodeMirror3 only rendersnpartial content, response time is nearly instant.nnIntraline differences can be hidden and shown by a trivial CSS classnbeing added or removed, making it very efficient for the user tontoggle this on or off. If the intraline data has not been loaded fromnthe server it is first loaded in the background, and then the view isnrendered again by updating the relevant markers and widgets.nnMost other properties (tab size, syntax highlighting, whitespace errors)nare easily set on the fly by updating CodeMirror with the new option.nnLines of context can now be directly entered by the user, or clearednto view the entire file with no skip bars.nnThe panel respects most of the diff preferences. Changing columnnwidth is unlikely to be supported, and skipping of uncommented andndeleted files will need a rewrite of PatchValidator.nnBug: issue 2165nInspired-by: Doug Kelly <doug.kelly@garmin.com>nChange-Id: I06e2305d723bd95b5f5eafcfe3bd1b827c8d3d9fn

Support controlling the submit type for changes from PrologSimilarly like the submit_rule there is now a submit_type predicatenwhich returns the allowed submit type for a change. When the submit_typenpredicate is not provided in the rules.pl then the project defaultnsubmit type is used for all changes for that project.nnFiltering the results of the submit_type is also supported in the samenway like filtering the results of the submit_rule. Using ansubmit_type_filter predicate one can enforce a particular submit typenfrom a parent project. For example, a release engineer may want tonenforce the FAST_FORWARD_ONLY submit type for all changes pushed tonstable release branches while, at the same time, use the project widendefault submit type for changes pushed to the development branch.nnChange-Id: Iec08f412723856b40324a6e0ec00ac523be9a3b6nSigned-off-by: Sasa Zivkov <sasa.zivkov@sap.com>n

Add possibility to override permissions from parent project.In case if local permissions have the same (category,group,ref) as anpermission from parent, then parents permission is overriden by thenlocal one.nnHere is an examplennParentProject (READ, group1, refs/*) -> [-1,1] # Allow groupA read projectnChildProject (READ, group1, refs/*) -> [-1,-1] # Override parents permission.n   # Now group1 cannot read the projectnnPay attention that is refspec is different from the parents permission,nthen the local permission *adds* rights. An example:nnParentProject (READ, group1, refs/*) -> [-1,1] # Allow groupA read projectnChildProject (READ, group1, refs/tags/*) -> [-1,-1]n # This permission does nothing as it adds [-1,-1] for refs/tags/*nnIn this case if you want to disallow to group1 read refs/tags/* then younneed to override parents permission first.nnParentProject (READ, group1, refs/*) -> [-1,1] # Allow groupA read projectnChildProject (READ, group1, refs/*) -> [-1,-1] # Override parents permissionnChildProject (READ, group1, -refs/tags/*) -> [-1,1]n # Explicitly says that group1 has access to everything except refs/tags/*nnChange-Id: If183e6255e4a1625b557e3bbc024093b18740d04n

Move ref_rights table into GitPermissions are stored in the project.config file within thenrefs/meta/config branch of each project.  This makes the rulesnmore flexible in the future, as well as adds version control.nnFor example:nn  [access refs/*]nowner = group tools-ownersnn  [access refs/heads/*]nlabel-Verified = -1..+1 group tools-devnlabel-Verified = -1..+1 group tools-ownersnlabel-Code-Review = -2..+2 group tools-ownersnsubmit = group tools-devnsubmit = group tools-ownersnn  [access refs/heads/stable]nexclusiveGroupPermissions = read create pushnread = group Anonymous Usersnpush = group tools-repo-maintainernnTo enable easy remote editing of the configuration rules, thenfollowing access block is added by default to -- All Projects --nand is thus inherited throughout the entire site:nn  [access refs/meta/config]nread = group Project Ownersnpush = group Project OwnersnnThis configuration section permits any project owner or sitenadministrator (as they are indirectly always a project owner ofnany project) to push changes to the project.config file withinnthe refs/meta/config branch, updating access (and other projectninformation) remotely without using the web UI.nnChange-Id: Idb56f657a4bf88108ad40bbb19d831e6806b68c5nSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Simplify CodeMirror wrapper JSNILineCharacter (aka {from, to} objects) is the same as Pos innCodeMirror.  The CodeMirror documentation suggests using a Posnobject in a number of function calls, but it can be unclear thisnis the LineCharacter wrapper in GerritnnRename LineCharacter to Pos, and change its factory methods tonconstruct using CodeMirror.Pos(line, ch) so instances are of thentype CodeMirror expects internally.nnSimplify accessor methods by dropping the get/set Java idiom andnuse the field name as the method name. Argument overloading makesnit possible to identify between a get and a set variant. This makesnthese lightweight JSNI wrappers feel more like an @AutoValue objectnor raw JavaScript code that they are interacting with.nnChange-Id: If73536652cc5559fcef5b2519cb686460a126ff5n

Access LabelTypes through ProjectState rather than globallyWe want to allow projects to define their own labels, so we cantnassume the label list is global. In typical cases, we can access itnthrough a ProjectControl, ChangeControl, or related factory. This doesnresult in a few more places where we propagatenNoSuchProject/ChangeExceptions where there were none before. This isnintended: operations that query/modify labels on, say, a barenChange.Id now do need to verify that the project/change exists.nnFor now, leave code in LabelTypesProvider, but try not to injectnLabelTypes where at all possible.nnChange-Id: I4936ccafdb41848aaac3e335adf4648369d6abbcn

Append approval info to every comment-added stream event and hookThis change is driven by the RFC proposal[1] to show labelntransitions more explicitly in Gerrit. Stream events onlynprovides label information on review events that containna vote transition.  When a user submits a review with only anreply message the approvals information is not added to thenstream event and hooks. This change will make Gerrit appendnapprovals info to every comment-added event including thenones that do not contain vote changes.nnSince labels are shown for every event we will add an oldValuenproperty to the approvalAttribute to distinguish when a votentransition has occurred.  The oldValue attribute containsnthe previous vote score.  This attribute will only appear whennthere is a vote transition.nnThe comment-added stream event will look like this:nn  approvals:[{type:Code-Review,description:Code-Review,n  value:-1, oldValue:0}, {type:Verified,n  description:Verified,value:0}],n  comment:Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1nnMy Message ...nnThis change will also a --$LabelName-oldValue parameter toncorresponding comment-added change hook:nn  hook[comment-added] output:n  --change I2cd8327360ff89338a4e7f0591bf0c037e9aa5dbn  --is-draft false --change-url http://localhost:8080/201n  --change-owner John Smith (jsmith@gmail.com) --project okcn  --branch master --author John Smith (jsmith@gmail.com)n  --commit 55079187f7ce1c461de804c13f2dd71d64a85280n  --comment Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1 --Code-Review -1n  --Code-Review-oldValue 0 --Verified 0nn[1] https://groups.google.com/d/msg/repo-discuss/soqmGjRpl-4/IIfAF4jbCQAJnnBug: Issue 3220nChange-Id: Ibc1c64d70e790c7b507db79931f31fd77f25e276n

Change permissions to be branch basedThe RefControl class introduces per-branch access control rules.nProjectRight is replaced by RefRight in the database, shifting allncurrent access records to include a reference pattern that matchesnthe previously assumed target namespace.  For example, PUSH_HEADnis now matched against refs/heads/*, as is SUBMIT.nnAlthough this implementation starts the foundation for per-branchnlevel READ access, it is not fully supported.  The Git nativenprotocol exposes all branches to readers, which means users cannstill fetch the Git objects even if the web UI wouldnt allow themnto see the change.nnThis work was a joint effort between Nico and Shawn.  Nico startednthe change and did the bulk of the implementation.  Shawn did anbunch of cleanup work near the tail end.  Consequently all bugsnare Shawns fault.nnBug: issue 60nChange-Id: I62401d80cbb885180614a4f20a945f5611de8986nSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

More refactoring of framework.Execute:* By default, execute() checks the return code of the process against 0.n  This can be changed using setReturnCode() and setIgnoreReturnCode().nn* Default working directory is now the projects base directory.nn* Tidied up tasks to reflect the new defaults.nnAbstractTask:nn* Made getBaseDirectory() and getService() protected.nnLogging:nn* Extracted AbstractLogger out of BasicLogger, and changed RoutingLogger ton  extend AbstractLogger, rather than BasicLogger.nn* RoutingLogger now uses a wrapped Logger to determine which message typesn  are enabled, so that it respects the logging level set on the command-line.n  Kinda hacky, but better than writing out all the debug messages.nn* Changed LoggingExecOutputHandler to use warn log level, rather than info.n  Again, a hacky fix to get logging of external command output happening whenn  not running in verbose mode.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@271890 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Add a way to change the destination of open changesWhen the development is moved from one branch to next in a git projectnand we want to get all the open changes from old branch to the new branch,nwe have to create a new copy of those changes for the new branch.nnSince these changes are not required on the old branch, moving would bena better fit than other propagation methods (cherrypicking, manual upload).nnThis change provides a REST API /changes/{change-id}/move tonmove an open change to a different branch.nnChange-Id: I44c68be1d08e2e1f4eab4e4f1724047f20072ac3n

Default temporary directory to $HOME/.gerritcodereview/tmpSome operating system distributions include a cron script whichncleans /tmp by unlinking any files not modified in the past 7 days.nThis can kill a running Gerrit server by deleting its JAR files,npreventing it from lazily-loading any code after the unlink occurs.nnWork around this by unpacking our JARs into a directory below thenusers home directory.  This matches the behavior of Hudson CI,nwhich also suffered from having their JARs disappear at runtimendue to these automatic /tmp cleaning scripts.nnChange-Id: Ia83c65d61310658fc9afd1c663b4b3877c457a3cnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Changes to DefaultConfigurer:* Uses the DataType role when creating instances for interface properties,n  rather than using the interface itself as the role.nn* Added ObjectConfigurer.getTypedProperty().  This replaces the implicitn  behaviour in DefaultObjectConfigurer.getProperty() where the typedn  property was returned for an unknown property name.nn* Typed properties are set using attributes and references, with then  propertys interface role shorthand name.  Previously, the DefaultConfigurern  would attempt to set the typed property for any unknown attribute orn  reference name.nn* Can have a set() method for a typed property, rather than an add() method.n  Same semantics as setX() and addX() methods.nn* Added a several more test cases.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@271227 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

* Rolled back change to PropertyResolver.resolveProperties(), so that it   uses a TaskContext again.  Added some regression tests.* Changed Embeddor.createWorkspace() to use a Map, rather than a Parameters,n  to supply initial workspace properties. Got rid of the Object -> String convertion fromn  <ant> and <antcall>.nn* Generalised ExecutionFrame, so that it can represent any execution scopen  (root, workspace, project, task, inherited, etc), rather than just task scope:n  - Replaced getTaskContext() with getPropertyStore().n  - Replaced getTypeManager() with getServiceManager().nn* Executor is now responsible for creating TaskContext.nn* Changed DefaultExecutor to use the configurer provided by the execution frame.nn* Added ExecutionContainer, a lifecycle interface which is used to supply then  root execution frame to a service which executes tasks (directly or indirectly).nn* Changed interaction between DefaultEmbeddor and workspaces.  Embeddor is nown  responsible for creating the base property store for workspaces.  ExecutionContainern  is used to pass this to workspaces. Several things all at once...* Bootstrap now passes args all the way throughn* FrontEnding implemented which allows Ant to talk back outn  to whatever front end might be driving it. Events propogatedn  are project start/end, target start/end, task start/end.n  This should allow any front end (like a GUI) to move an  progress indicator through a display of the object tree.n  Also included is a generic writeMessage(String, int) method.n* cli/Main now plays ClassLoader games so that it can auton  matically place needed resources (like tools.jar) inton  the classpath space of the executing Ant. Note -- thisn  is the first of a few steps to make complicated shelln  launch scripts unnecessary. All that should be donen  is a single executable per platform that essentiallyn  calls java -jar anteater.jar [args]. Main is alson  primed for a future CJAN so that it can download whatevern  jars are needed from CJAN and place them into the classpathn  space of the executing Ant. Of course, its not implementedn  yet since CJAN isnt around yet -- but its ready. :)n* AntException now has fields for embedding the locationn  of an Error. Next up will be implementing the coden  around where Tasks are run so that exceptions will containn  this information.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@268333 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Rewrite MergeOp to use BatchUpdateThere are a number of major architectural changes here. At a highnlevel, instances of SubmitStrategy no longer actually touch the reponor changes directly; the only public method is now:nn  public void addOps(BatchUpdate bu, Set<CodeReviewCommit> toMerge)n  throws IntegrationException;nnThus the main loop in MergeOp#integrateIntoHistory creates a submitnstrategy for each branch, adds its ops to a BatchUpdate, and thennexecutes the update. Some of the validation steps (which arenread-only) as well as submodule operations still happen outside thenmain BatchUpdate.nnThe next major change is moving all of the post-submit-strategynvalidation and change updating logic out of MergeOp. This has beennsplit across two other basic locations.nnThe first location is SubmitStrategyOp, which is a common abstractnbase class of ops created by SubmitStrategy implementations. Thisncontains the logic to update the branch and change status based on thenactual meat of the submit strategy implementation. It handles thingsnlike updating refs, writing out ChangeMessages, firing hooks, etc.nSubmitStrategy guarantees that there is exactly one SubmitStrategyOpnper input CodeReviewCommit that gets merged. Implementations mayncreate a smaller set of ops, for example a single FastForwardOp tonmerge the first few commits in a series. SubmitStrategy fills in thengaps and adds an ImplicitIntegrateOp to the update for each changenthat needs to be validated even if it was not set up initially by thenSubmitStrategy.nnThe second location for validation uses the newly addednBatchUpdate.Listener interface. The SubmitStrategyListenernimplementation uses the problem map stored in the new CommitStatusnclass to abort the process after updating the repo or updatingnchanges. It also does some checks that are more appropriate afternrunning _all_ submit strategies in the batch, like checking thenCommitMergeStatus bit on all the input CodeReviewCommits.nnOne goal of this rewrite is to make fully implementing the notedb partnof MergeOp more feasible, but apart from that, there are somenbehavioral and organizational differences resulting from this changenthat I believe are overall beneficial.nnFirst, the main feature of BatchUpdate is that it follows anwell-defined order of operations: all ObjectInserters are flushednbefore any ref updates are written; all ref updates are written as an(per-repo) batch; and each change is updated in a transaction. Sincenthe merge process does all of these things, it will receive thesenperformance and consistency improvements as a result.nnSecond, this change deletes several hundred lines from MergeOp, makingnit somewhat less of a kitchen sink. Instead most of the behavior isndecomposed into batch update operations. There is some cognitive costnto this in terms of communicating between phases using shared state,nbut I hope that overall the decomposition is worth it.nnChange-Id: I1d9883a515729f9085709dd0ec85f9ba3c5a6152n

Print proper name for ListenableFutureTask in show-queue commandAny Gerrit WorkQueue.Executor that is decorated by a GuavanMoreExecutors.listeningDecorator was not printing the proper task namenin show-queue command. Even if the task defined a toString method, thentoString method of the ListenableFutureTask was called instead.nnSince the task that we need to call the toString is wrapped into anFutureTask which is also wrapped into a ListenableFutureTask, there isnno clean way to call proper toString other than modifying both classesnto delegate the toString to task they are wrapping.nnModify WorkQueue.Task.toString method to call the proper toString methodnby reflection when the task is a ListenableFutureTask.nnChange-Id: I551a89e88c4961b7412ff732bf47e2e3e9f3352fn

Use Prolog Cafe for ChangeControl.canSubmit()Re-implement the canSubmit() logic in Prolog, removing one of thenlast uses of FunctionState.  This is a simple re-implementationnthat does not provide any new functionality.nnPatchSetApproval objects are exposed into Prolog on demand bynloading them from the database if the submit predicate needsnthem. These get indexed in a temporary HashMap by their label namen(aka ApprovalCategory), making access faster during evaluation ofnthe rule.nnApprovalTypes are loaded into Prolog on demand from the GuicenInjector.  This will eventually go away when we get rid of thenglobal declaration of ApprovalCategories in the web UI.nnCurrentUser instances are loaded and cached within the Prolognenvironment as needed to consider PatchSetApproval objects and ifnthe user has the necessary permission to make that assertion.nnBug: 971nChange-Id: I7e261948db08b7c3180e590e81f492ff3e6f237enSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

First attempt at optimizing the zip code to have decent performance The performance problem was mainly due to the entry insertion in the hashtable where all hash code were equals in the hashtable. I also removed a lot of unecessary Zip(Long|Short) object creation by adding static methods and suppressed a hashtable.More can be done, but I tried not to break the interface and have as less codenas possible. Error out if a user forgets to squash when replacing a patchThis condition happens when a user makes a second commit and tries tonreplace it onto an existing change, e.g. if they did:nn  $ git commitn  $ repo uploadn  ... some time later ...nn  $ git commitn  $ repo upload --replace .n ... specify the prior change ...nnGerrit sees that the change depends upon itself, as the latest patch setnhas an ancestor that is a prior patch set of the same change.  This is anvery simple case to detect and error out on during upload, ensuring thatnthe user has an opportunity to correct their usage.nnBug: GERRIT-137nSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

First version of the <systemPath>.You need to include ant-sax2.jar in ant/lib, define a <path id=foo> that includesnall the jars that you need ( junit.jar, etc ) and then usen <systemPath pathRef=foo /> to create the loader and reload all optional tasks.nnAfter this step all optional tasks will work in the same way as if you havenincluded the jars from the <path> definition in ant/lib.nnI did some basic tests and seems to work fine - note that <taskdef> willnwork as before, i.e. if you explicitely define tasks that need optionalnjars ( or redefine optional task ), youll have the old behavior ( i.e.nrequire things in CLASSPATH ).nnIll try to find what changes are need for <import> and re-do the buildnfor ant-sax2, then do more testings.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@273118 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

First part of the Servlet3 web-fragment support. This patch inserts a stage into the web.xml processing. web.xml files are now parsed and loaded into an instance of WebXml and then that WebXml instance is used to configure the context. This will allow the subsequent addition of parsing and merging web-fragment.xml files. The hooks are in place to add this functionality but it has not yet been written. With the patch applied, the Servlet 2.5 TCK and JSP 2.1 TCK pass with the exception of the Servlet version number checks.git-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@816951 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Wait for dependencies to submit before claiming merge failureInstead of emailing when a dependency is missing, wait a short bitnfor that dependency to submit first.  This makes it a bit cleanernto start at the tip of a chain of commits and work backwards,nas we no longer generate missing dependency emails at every step.nnThis does not totally address issue 67 as that issue talks aboutnlooking for descendants during submit and waiting for those to enternthe submit queue before continuing.  But this is a nice steppingnstone in that direction by providing for the delay queue which wencould use to retry.nnBug: GERRIT-67 (issue 67)nChange-Id: Ibe66d7c844141ae101a0e145f201232d0fc91f4dnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Dynamic properties and a bit more.This is slightly different from embed - if dynamic properties will benaccepted in 1.6, it is better to do it right. Embed uses few hacks tontrick the ProjectHelper.nnPropertyHelper includes all the code related with property manipulationnfrom Project (cut&paste). I added a very simple hook mechanism ( Filter/Valvenlike ) for the most common operations.nnThe API is obviously far from final - someone who really understand usernand inherited properties should review it and make few changes.nnIn Project, all properties fields are private - so all can be removed.nThe methods related with properties will just delegate to PropertyHelper.nFrom a user point of view - no visible change ( hopefully :-). Even grantnwill continue to work ( but wont be able to use the new features ).nnBenefits:n- cleanup of Project. Less code and better organised.n- Property handling will hopefully be cleaner toon- we get to add APIs for namespace support, and maybe support non-stringnproperties ( JSP-EL like - that needs to be disussed, but IMO it wouldnbe very helpfull ). While refs are Objects, the main distinction is imutability.nnAlso:n- apps embeding or extending ant can fully customize _all_ aspects ofnproperty processing, including ${} replacement and even the syntax.n- it should be very easy to hook a different storage mechanism ( i.e.nintegrated with the embeding app, without requiring copy of properties ).n- it should be possible to avoid copy when creating execution framesn( by using a chain that keeps changes and delegates getters ).n- dynamic properties support ( my original itch :-)nnPlease wait few days before firing, it seems all tests are passingnand gump works - but Im sure there are few problems :-)nn( Ill commit the change in Project later today )nnPR:nObtained from:nSubmitted by:nReviewed by:nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@273709 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Bring over the merge code from Gerrit1 and merge changes upon submissionThis brings in the core of the merge logic from Gerrit1, housed innMergeOp and MergeSorter.  These are largely unmodified from theirnversion in Gerrit1, but the package was changed and the input/outputnwas modified to use Gerrits ReviewDb database connection rather thanna Google protobuf message buffer.nnImmediately after submission we try to merge any pending changes fornthe current branch, but we limit the number of threads trying to mergenany branch to 1.  If there is already a thread trying to merge on thatnbranch we mark a flag and use a background thread to perform to retrynthe merge once the current thread finishes.nnFor the most part the current web thread will be able to issue the mergenimmediately, as generally any given branch will be idle.  If a branch isnbusy it will usually finish within the next second and the the backgroundnthread can restart the branchs merge.  Either way a merge will appear tonbe instant (or virtually instant) to the end-user.nnTheres a number of race conditions and/or poor error handling still innthis code.  Since the bulk of it is directly copied in from Gerrit1 I amnleaving it unchanged, and will address these bugs in future commits.nnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

ClassLoader hierarchy changes:* Use multi-parent ClassLoaders for antlibs and extensions, so that eachn  extension jar is loaded by a single ClassLoader in the hierarchy.  Allowsn  classes from extensions to be shared across dependent antlibs and extensions.nn* Changed contract of ClassLoaderManager.createClassLoader( File[] ), so thatn  it creates a new ClassLoader each time it is called.nn* Changed ExtensionManager, so that it no longer extends PackageRepository.nn* Added a few test cases for DefaultClassLoaderManager.nn* Moved responsibility for checking myrmidon.home and building the various paths,n  from DefaultEmbeddor and DefaultExtensionManager to EmbeddedAnt.  Use then  platform path separator for the paths, rather than the | char.nn* Use EmbeddedAnt in AbstractProjectTest, rather than using an Embeddor directly.nn* AbstractComponentTest was not parameterising or initialising the testn  components.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@272180 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Assign a unique UUID to each AccountGroupUUIDs will be used later on to link access rules to groups, even ifnthe group gets renamed and the access rule file didnt get updatednwith the new name yet.nnTo generate a UUID we take the creator of the group and the originalngroup name and hash them with SHA-1.  This should produce a globallynunique identifier that is also time dependent, as the PersonIdentnhas the current time embedded as part of the creator string.nnThe placeholder group Project Owners is assigned a constant UUID,nas the concept of project ownership is the same across all serversnand the server interpreting the rules needs to replace this groupnwith the actual ownership list before evaluating them.nnThe magic groups Anonymous Users and Registered Users are alsonassigned constant UUIDs, as this simplifies the definition of thosenautomatic membership groups within a server installation.nnChange-Id: I47119b325418f88e089e136cee47593d82fbc754nSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Improve error handling for an unhandled exception after the response has been committed. Tomcat will now attempt to: - flush any unwritten response data to the client - prevent further writes to the response - close the connectionThis means that the client should experience an unclean close that will enable them to differentiate (when chunked encoding is used) between an incomplete response that encountered an error and a complete response that did not (prior to this commit, Tomcat completed the request normally and - depending on the response data written to that point - it may not have been visible to the client that the response was incomplete at that point.nngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@1600449 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Fix race condition in checking topic mergeabilityThe list of changes in the topic is looked up using the secondarynindex, which prepopulates the mergeable field on the ChangeData. Thisnvalue may be stale, as it is just a boolean yes/no, suitablenprimarily for rendering the search results list. In particular, itnmay not reflect the current state of the branch tip, if thenReindexAfterUpdate queue has not yet been fully processed.nnActionsIT was hitting this race condition by submitting a change thennimmediately checking the mergeability of a change conflicting with thennew branch tip. The mergeability of this second change should switchnfrom true to false as a result (blocking submission of the wholentopic). Because of this race condition, it was indeterminate whichnmergeability bit would be returned from the search index.nnThe workaround for now is to allow explicitly clearing the mergeablenbit in ChangeData. A more robust change would be to tweak the indexnsystem to say we want to prepopulate the ChangeData with fewer storednfields from the index. As InternalChangeQuery is used more, this maynbecome more and more important.nnChange-Id: I847c7896371451b85a05f4d768b805b953b61466n

Here are two new ant tasks - BZip2 and BUnzip2. u00efu00bfu00bdThese two tasks use the BZip2 compression algorithm (Visit: http://sourceware.cygnus.com/bzip2/u00efu00bfu00bdfor more info.) for packing and unpacking.These tasks resemble GZip and GUnzip tasks in input,ninput validation, etc. u00efu00bfu00bdHence, I refactored GZip andnGUnzip tasks as well so that the tasks GZip and BZip2nextend from a common base class named Pack, andnGUnzip and BUnzip2 extend from a common base class namednUnpack. u00efu00bfu00bdThis lays the foundation for creating more Packntasks based on different algorithms like lzop, etc. innthe future.nnThe BZip2 and BUnzip2 tasks depend upon 4 classes:nBZip2Constants.javanCBZip2InputStream.javanCBZip2OutputStream.javanCRC.javannKeiron Liddle (keiron@aftexsw.com) has graciouslynaccepted to contribute the above code files he hasnauthored, under ASF license - many thanks to him. u00efu00bfu00bdInhave packaged them under org.apache.tools.bzip2,nmimicking the package naming style that has been usednfor zip and tar tools we already have. u00efu00bfu00bdI have alsongiven proper credits to him in the code. u00efu00bfu00bdPerhaps, thisnneeds to exist under jakarta-commons, as Stefan hadnsuggested, but till then...nnSubmitted by: Magesh Umasankar <umagesh@rediffmail.com>nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@269919 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Search for resource using the thread context class loader under Java2. If that fails, search for resource using the class loader that loaded this class (Loader). Under JDK 1.1, only the the class loader that loaded this class (Loader) is used.Try one last time with ClassLoader.getSystemResource(resource),nthat is is using the system class loader in JDK 1.2 and virtualnmachines built-in class loader in JDK 1.1.nnThe difference with the previous code was that under Java2, thenclassloader of org.apache.log4j.helpers.Loader was *not* tried if thenthread context loader was set. However, this is incorrect logic becasenThread.getContextClassLoader always returns a value.nnThread.getContextClassLoader javadoc reads:nn Returns the context ClassLoader for this Thread. The contextn ClassLoader is provided by the creator of the thread for use by coden running in this thread when loading classes and resources. If not set,n the default is the ClassLoader context of the parent Thread. Then context ClassLoader of the primordial thread is typically set to then class loader used to load the application.nnIf an application server chooses not to set the thread context classnloader, then Thread.getContextClassLoader returns the classpathnclassloader which usually not what is desired.nnnPR:nObtained from:nSubmitted by:nReviewed by:nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/logging/log4j/trunk@309345 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Various microoptimizations to reduce I/O load of common tasks, esp. no-op <javac> and <depend>. Many inner loops altered to make just 1-2 system calls rather than 4-5. You can easily see how wasteful the previous code was, and find the culprits, by patching r/o java.io.File methods and adding to -Xbootclasspath/p (or use AspectJ). E.g.:public boolean isDirectory() {n  System.err.println(isDirectory:  + this); if (Math.random() < .01) Thread.dumpStack();n  // as before...n}nnAnt still makes an order of magnitude more system calls to do what seem like simple operationsnthan you would think necessary, but this patch should at least improve the situation.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@581748 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Prepare to receive uploads into Gerrit by git push over SSHUsers can now use git push ssh://$email@$host:$port/$project.gitnto upload changes into Gerrit.  The tip commit must be pushed intonthe special ref refs/changes/new, and updates to existing changesnshould be pushed to refs/changes/nn/ccnn/new.nnAdditional data like --reviewer and --cc (to force specific reviewnstatus) can be supplied as optional arguments to the extended servernside command gerrit-receive-pack, such as:nn git push n --receive-pack=gerrit-receive-pack --cc=sop@google.com --reviewer=sop@google.com n ssh://sop@google.com@gerrit-dev:29418/tools/gerrit.git n devwork:refs/changes/newnnUsing the --receive-pack argument to force additional CC informationnis probably best left to a wrapper program like repo, as the commandnline can otherwise get quite long.nnAttempting to push to any other ref other than the two special formsnof new results in an error, as Gerrit does not normally want tonpermit remote deletes or force-updates of branches.  This mightnchange in the future on a per-project basis.nnChange entities are not yet created, nor are existing changes updatednwith new commit information.  This work is left for a future change.nnSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Throw RestApiException from BatchUpdate#execute()Allows constituent operations to indicate that they should use anparticular error code when run in an HTTP context, without requiringnexception unwrapping and rethrowing at call sites. In the short term,nthis means more exception types thrown in various places, but the hopenis that over time those methods will throw RestApiException andnUpdateException only.nnChange-Id: Ic863624369baacc94b675f50b4c1f4a022b9f5den

Added MailMessage.  Hope people dont mind that I left it in com.oreilly.servlet.  I did that since its going to be a mirror of whats in the larger com.oreilly.servlet package.  I put it under the Apache license of course, and added the ASF as an additional copyright holder.  Code can have two copyright holders, meaning either party can do as they wish with the code.  This lets the ASF upgrade to Apache License 1.2 sometime in the future, and lets me be able to use the code without thanking the ASF for code I wrote.  :-)  Updated build.xml to handle the new package.git-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@267693 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

The http implementation - it may be hard to recognize the original connector code from tomcat after many iterations. Changes compared with coyote: - both server and client mode - HttpRequest/HttpResponse implement most of methods in the HttpServletRequest - with the addition of setters, for use in client mode. They dont implement the interfaces - or servlet framework specific methods - but should look familiar to people using this as a library - mapping is moved in this package, also support running HttpServices in the selector thread (proxy will run this way) - MimeHeaders are gone, so are the parameters - replaced with the MultiMap, which is based on MimeHeaders but adds a HashMap instead of linear scanning See tests for examples.git-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@884412 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Added the TaskFactory and modified Project.This is not organized as a project - the files here needs to replacenthe ones in the main tree. Ill probably import the rest of the corenand make it a standalone replacement, so its easy to review.nnThe goals are to:n- make ant more embeddablen- integrate it better in other toolsn- support SAX2 and namespacesn- support pluggable behavior for the XML readern- support pluggable task factories - the factory will have full controlnover the class loadern- better support and integration with existing java beans.nnAll that while maintaining full compatibility with ant1.4 - allnthe code here is just an additional set of hooks, with the previousnbehavior preserved and remaining as default.nnEventually this can be refactored into a standalone componentnthat will implement a task engine for ant1.x.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@271572 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Enable smart HTTP under /p/ URLsThe new smart HTTP Git protocol is now supported through the Gerritnweb application context by using the URL /p/$project.git.nnLike SSH, push requires user authentication.  However, sincenuser authentication is currently based solely upon HTTP cookies,nand cookies arent supported by the C Git command line client,nusing push is not currently possible.  We need to introduce ournown password based user authentication process.nnChange-Id: I76a894226a583ce6f47fd246f7d0f88b77ea4505nSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n

Changes to the VFS data types:* Added FileSelector interface.nn* <v-fileset> now takes file selectors, instead of include and exclude patterns.nn* Added a bunch of file selector implementations:n  * <and>, <or>, <not> for combining selectors.n  * <name>, <basename>, <url> for testing bits of the file name againstnan Ant 1 style pattern, or a regular expression.n  * <is-file>, <is-folder>, <exists> for testing file type.nn* Added <flat-fileset>, which combines nested file sets and paths into an  single directory.  This allows explicit path -> fileset conversion.nn* Added <filtered-path>, which applies selectors to nested file sets and paths.nn* Added <list-fileset> debug task.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@271577 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

SideBySide2: Rewrite padding mechanism to be based on diff chunksCalculating padding line-by-line is very slow on large changes.nRewrite padding to be based on the size of each diff chunk,nqueried using the heightAtLine() method provided by CodeMirror.nnThis new mechanism also takes care of calculating the padding fornany CommentBox appearing in a diff chunk. PaddingManager is now usednonly for CommentBoxes not in diff chunks. Eventually the paddingnlogic will be unified and PaddingManager will be deleted.nnChange-Id: I85dd48d5e3448bca3ae7316b4b9c9d13388dd139n

First pass at using the new resources implementation to provide resources to the class loader.Class loader resources are handled by treating JARs in WEB-INF/lib asnresource JARs (without the internal META-INF/resources/ prefix) mountednat WEB-INF/claasses (rather than the web app root). This enables reusenof the resource handling plumbing.nnThese resources are marked as class loader only so they are only used innthe methods that are explicitly defined to return class loadernresources. This prevents calls to getResource(/WEB-INF/classes)nreturning from one or more of the JAR files.nngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@1538807 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

2 small (?) changes.References are stored in a special hashtable that automaticallynconfigures UnknownElements. ( this will probably be a noop withnthe current execution model most of the times - since ProjectHelpernalready does that ).nnAlso task and type creation is delayed and not all tasks arenconstructed. That should remove few seconds from the startup time,nand will simplify a lot of code that modifies the classpath atnruntime.nnPlease review - and if you see any problem -1 it. I checked it innmostly to allow other people to verify the Script with lazyneval. If there are objections I can turn this into a hooknand move it to [embed].nnPR:nObtained from:nSubmitted by:nReviewed by:nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@273620 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Updated ProjectHelper.I used the current sources ( with the new comments), and reimplementednall changes.nnThe current version doesnt have anything related with the other proposals,nand is functionally equivalent with the old ProjectHelper - except itsncleaner ( all private and SAX code moved to the helper imple ).nnI created a new package, o.a.t.ant.helper to keep the core cleaner -nother helpers may be commited.nnThe SAX2 based helper is easy to write, but depends on few improvementsnon RoleFactory ( createTask with namespace support, etc ).nIm working on a new implementation of the task factory, with supportnfor data types and other roles - but thats another story.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@271735 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

VFS Additions:* Added FileSelector, which allows files to be chosen when doing recursiven  operations.  Added a couple of implementations.  Added a selector parametern  to FileObject.delete() and copy().nn* Added FileObject.replicateFile(), which converts a FileObject into a local File.nn* Moved replication code out of the Zip provider, into a shared FileReplicatorn  component.  The implemenation is pretty brain-dead, but at very least shouldn  properly clean up temporary files in ant_vfs_cache.  Also, local files willn  no longer be replicated, but used directly.nn* Added FileName.getRelativeName(), and NameScope.DESCENDENT_OR_SELF.nn* Now handles providers which are LogEnabled and Disposable.nn* Made the local file provider pluggable.nn* Providers are now responsible for thier own caching.nn* FTP and Zip providers clean up properly.  Fixed FTP directory delete.nnngit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/ant/core/trunk@272262 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Recover from merges that failed after updateRepoSince were now batching more change operations together into a singlentransaction, the chance of a failure causing the changes state andncurrent patch set to not be updated is higher. Prior to usingntransactions, this happened relatively early in the process.nnTry harder to recover from this state: before attempting to merge anchange, see whether some patch set ref of that change has already beennmerged, and if so, just fix up the state and patch set record.nnThis ends up being pretty complicated, and requires doing a bunch ofnisMergedInto checks prior to merging. Hopefully in practice there arennot so many patch sets and/or they are close enough to head to notnmake this too expensive.nnTesting is a little tricky too. Teach Submit to accept a specialnSubmitInput that tells SubmitStrategyListener to abort at a certainnphase, simulating some real-world failures.nnChange-Id: I6922b5970c10fd9e074c1979d9eddb9103ac5d4fn

This is the first draft of the refactored coyote connector. Lots of big changes: - MessageBytes is gone - BBuffer, CBuffer are used as buffers, BBucket/CBucket are used for wrapping bytes - C2B/B2C are gone - replaced by nio charsets in IOReader/IOWriter. CBuffer is still needed (instead of a StringBuilder ) to have access to the raw chars and avoid copy - speaking of copy, IOChannel uses a list of buffers instead of growing a buffer. For proxy we should be able to move buffers from in to out.  This works a bit better with the char conversions, etc - Nio code heavily refactored - I didnt add APR but shouldnt be hard if anyonew wants. - Ssl is barely working - needs improvementsgit-svn-id: https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/tomcat/trunk@884410 13f79535-47bb-0310-9956-ffa450edef68n

Implement new /changes/{id}/action style REST APIAll existing JSON APIs are converted to this new style.nn/changes/{id} parses the id field from a JSON response from a priornresponse and uses that to uniquely identify a change and verify thencaller can see it. If the user requests only /changes/{id}/ then thendata is returned as a single JSON object.nnThis commit also gives full remote control of plugins using then/plugins/ namespace:nn  PUT /plugins/{name}(JAR as request body)n  POST /plugins/{name}   (JSON object {url:https://...})n  DELETE /plugins/{name}n  GET /plugins/{name}/gerrit~statusn  POST /plugins/{name}/gerrit~reloadn  POST /plugins/{name}/gerrit~enablen  POST /plugins/{name}/gerrit~disablennThe commit provides some project admin commands:nn  GET /projects/{name}/descriptionn  PUT /projects/{name}/descriptionnn  GET /projects/{name}/parentn  PUT /projects/{name}/parentnnProject dashboards have moved:nn  GET /projects/{name}/dashboardsn  GET /projects/{name}/dashboards/{id}n  GET /projects/{name}/dashboards/defaultnnTo access project names containing /, the name must be encoded withnURL encoding, translating / to %2F.nnChange-Id: I6a38902ee473003ec637758b7c911f926a2e948an

Allow ?s=0 to disable server side permutation selectionThe permutation selection algorithm should always work, but itnmight fail on a weird browser combination we havent seen beforenthat was working through the standard GWT selection process.nnIf the user manually adds ?s=0 to the URL we skip the server sidenselection and use the stock nocache.js to allow the client tonperform the permutation selection.  It shouldnt ever be necessary,nbut its good to have an escape hatch.nnChange-Id: I192df745199aba3cfc8eca5b5adf509bdb280d9enSigned-off-by: Shawn O. Pearce <sop@google.com>n
